abstracts.cdata!:
The Urban Development Project in Lesotho
            was achieved. The project has been a major force in
            introducing lower cost, affordable standards for housing and
            related infrastructure, and these standards have been
            generally accepted. However, the experience in building
            roads and drainage suggests a need for deeper analysis of
            the traffic patterns prior to undertaking work in an
            existing residential area. Standards in this case were too
            low considering the then current and expected future levels
            of traffic, and from the viewpoint of recurrent cost
            implications. A more realistic assessment would have avoided
            the need for substantial maintenance of roads constructed
            during the project and an eventual upgrading of these roads
            to permanent surfacing also during the project, incurring an
            additional cost of about 0.5 million.
